3D hierarchical porous ZnFe2O4 nano/micro structure as a highperformance anode material for lithium-ion batteries

Keywords: Lithium-ion batteries ZnFe2O4 Anode materials Energy storage and conversion Nanoparticles
3D porous nano/micro ZnFe2O4 has been prepared from the leach liquor of jarosite residue via a facile chemical coprecipitation method followed by sintering at 800 C in air atmosphere. As anode material for lithium ion batteries, the prepared ZnFe2O4 exhibits high specific capacity, excellent rate capability, and good cycling stability, which can be due to the beneficial effects of primary nanocrystals of ZnFe2O4, the unique 3D porous nano/micro structure, and the associated pseudo-capacitive behavior during discharge/charge processes.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are widely used in portable electronics, electric vehicles, and off-grid power supply system [1]. However, the commercial graphite anode suffers from limitations of low theoretical capacity ( 372 mAhg 1), unfavorable rate capability, and safety concerns, and cannot satisfy the rapid growing demands for higher energy density/power density and better safety [2,3]. In recent years, mixed transition-metal oxides (MTMOs) have attracted increasing attention as promising anode materials for LIBs [4–7]. Among various TTMOs materials, ZnFe2O4 stands out from the others because of its low cost, environmental friendliness, and especially high theoretical capacity ( 1000 mAh g 1) [8–12]. However, the practical application of ZnFe2O4 anode material is still hampered by poor cycling stability and bad rate capability [10,13–16]. Constructing nanostructured materials is an effective way to tackle these issues [17–19]. So far, various nanostructured ZnFe2O4 materials have been reported and these materials showed enhanced lithium storage performance compared to bulk ZnFe2O4. Note that the preparation methods of these nanostructured ZnFe2O4 are generally involving complicated steps and high cost due to high requirement of equipment and/or expensive raw materials [10,12], which seriously restrict the development and application of ZnFe2O4. Therefore,
exploring facile and cost-efficient methods for producing nanostructured ZnFe2O4 material with high electrochemical performance is urgently needed.
Herein, we reported a facile and low-cost method to fabricate 3D porous nano/micro ZnFe2O4 utilizing the leach liquor of jarosite residue. When evaluated as anode material for LIBs, this ZnFe2O4 sample displayed high reversible capacity, excellent cycling stability, and superior high-rate capability.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
The 3D porous nano/micro ZnFe2O4 is prepared from the leach liquor (containing 44 mM Zn2+ and 121 mM Fe2+) of jarosite residue (the nature of this residue is provided in the Supplementary Data). In a typical synthesis, 1.65 mM ZnSO4 7H2O was dissolved in 100 mL leach liquor, so that the Zn2+/Fe3+ molar ratio in the solution is 1/2. Afterwards, 120 mL Na2CO3 aqueous solution (0.94 M) was slowly added in the above mixed solution under stirring at room temperature. After reaction for 3 h, the precipitation settled down overnight, then separated by filtration, washed with distilled water, and freeze dried to get the precursor (Fig. S2). Finally, the precursor was dispersed in 0.62 M ammonium citrate solution (the weight ratio of precursor/ammonium citrate is 1:15) and sintered at 800 C in air for 2 h to obtain the final ZnFe2O4 (Fig. 1a).
X-ray diffraction (XRD, Dutch PANalytica X’Pert3 powder using Cu Ka radiation), scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU5000), transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL
JEM-2100F), 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy (MFD-500A), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250) were performed on sample to research its microstructure.
Electrochemical performance was evaluated in 2016 coin-type cells with lithium foil as both counter/reference electrodes. The working electrodes were constructed by coating the slurry of the ZnFe2O4, carbon black, and PVDF (with a mass ratio of 6/3/1) dissolved in NMP onto a Cu foil substrate. Celgard 2400 membrane was used as separator. The electrolyte was 1 M LiPF6 solution, composing of EC, DEC, and DC with a volume ratio of 1/1/1. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out on a CHI760E electrochemical workstation. Galvanostatic discharge/charge tests were performed on a Neware BTS-5 V/10 mA battery tester.

sections.heading: 3.1. Structure characterization
sections.text:
Fig. 1b shows the XRD pattern of the ZnFe2O4 sample. All the diffraction peaks can be indexed to spinel ZnFe2O4 (JCPDS 89- 7412). As shown in Fig. 1c, the room temperature 57Fe Mössbauer spectrum of the ZnFe2O4 sample can be well fitted with two doublets (doublets A and B as listed in Table S1). Doublet A can be assigned to the Fe3+ occupying tetrahedral sites [20]. Thus, the site occupation in the sample can be expressed as (Zn0.66Fe0.34)tet [Zn0.34Fe1.66]octO4. Fig. 3d displays the Fe 2p spectrum of the ZnFe2O4 sample. The two main peaks at 711 and 725 eV can be

ascribled to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively [12]. The satellite peaks at 719 eV conforming the oxidation state of iron in the sample is Fe(III) [21]. The Zn 2p spectrum (Fig. S3) shows two intense peaks at 1021.4 and 1044.5 eV, verifying the oxidation state of zinc is Zn(II) [22].
As shown in Fig. 2a, the ZnFe2O4 presents a 3D hierarchically porous morphology, which is related to the emission of gaseous species through decomposition of precursor and ammonium citrate during sintering. The co-continuous skeletons are constructed by primary particles with the average size of 30 nm (Fig. 2b). HRTEM image (Fig. 2c) demonstrated that the nanoparticles are attached to each other in various orientations. This 3D porous nano/micro structure would shorten Li+ diffusion distance, facilitate electrolyte penetration, and alleviate volume change during charge/discharge processes, which are crucial parameters for enhancing the lithium storage performance. EDS mappings (Fig. 2d–g) verified that the Fe, Zn, and O elements are homogenously distributed in the samples.
Fig. 3a gives the CV curves of the ZnFe2O4 electrode. In the first cathodic sweep, the two obvious reduction peaks at 0.82 and 0.67 V can be ascribed to the reduction of Fe2+ and Zn2+ to Fe0 and Zn0 and the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film [23,24]. For the first anodic sweep, the broad oxidation peak at 1.55 V can be associated with the oxidation of Zn0 and Fe0 into
ZnO and Fe2O3 [12,25]. Fig. 3b shows the cycling performance of the ZnFe2O4 electrode at 500 and at 1000 mA g 1. The discharge capacity declines sharply during the initial tens of cycles, and then ascends steadily in the subsequent hundred cycles. This phenomenon is generally attributed to the reversible growth of polymetric gel-like film originating from electrolyte degradation [26]. The reversible discharge capacity retains as 1371 (1140) mAh g 1 after 300 (7 0 0) cycles at 500 (1000) mA g 1, which is superior to the nanostructured ZnFe2O4 anodes reported previously (Table S2). Fig. 3c presents the rate capability of the ZnFe2O4 electrode after activation at 500 mA g 1 for 130 cycles. The electrode delivers discharge capacities of 1002, 939, 786, and 689 mAh g 1 at the current densities of 500, 1000, 3000, and 5000 mA g 1, respectively, which is competitive with other nanostructured ZnFe2O4 materials (Fig. S4). The charge storage mechanism of the ZnFe2O4 electrode was analyzed by sweep voltammetry method [27,28]. In this method, the contributions from pseudo-capacitive effect (k1v) and diffusion-controlled (k2v1/2) process can be quantified using the CV profiles at different sweep rates (v) (Fig. 3d) according to the following equation: i(V) = k1v + k2v1/2 (details for calculations are provided in the Supplementary Data). The capacitive contribution increases with an increase in sweep rate (Fig. 3e– g), and finally reaches 67% at 2.5 mV s 1 (Fig. 3h), which accounts for the high rate capability.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
3D porous nano/micro ZnFe2O4 was successfully synthesized from the leach liquor of jarosite residue. Benefiting from the structural advantages and pseudo-capacitive effect, this 3D porous nano/micro ZnFe2O4 exhibits high reversible capacity, excellent rate capability, and superior cycling stability when evaluated as anode material for LIBs. The strategy reported in this work provides a new way for preparing high performance ZnFe2O4 anode materials from industrial wastes, which has practical significance in terms of both social and economic aspects.
